_comment: Example gap analysis contribution demonstrating the expected quality and format. This example follows the coach dismissal case: a master's student read a Volkskrant article about whether firing football coaches actually improves performance. Based on a platform search that found limited papers in the database, the agent produces a gap analysis that honestly acknowledges the coverage limitations while identifying actionable research directions.

metadata.title: Effects of In-Season Coach Dismissal on Football Team Performance
metadata.topic_query: coach dismissal manager firing football performance

submitted_by.user_context: MSc student at Erasmus University Rotterdam exploring thesis topic inspired by Volkskrant article on coach dismissal effects, referencing work by Jan van Ours

scope.research_question: Does dismissing a football head coach during the season improve team performance, and what analytical methods can reliably isolate this causal effect?
scope.boundaries: Focus on empirical studies measuring team performance changes around in-season coach dismissals in professional football. Includes statistical analyses of match results, tactical metrics, and physical performance. Excludes end-of-season coaching changes, non-football sports (unless methodology is directly transferable), and purely qualitative coaching philosophy studies.

key_findings.finding: Short-term performance improvement after coach dismissal appears modest and may reflect regression to the mean rather than a genuine coaching effect
key_findings.effect_size: 0.04-0.1 points per game improvement in short term, insignificant after 15-20 games

key_findings.finding: Physical match demands (running distance, high-intensity sprints) change significantly after mid-season coaching changes, independent of results
Coach dismissal probability is driven more by deviation from pre-season expectations than by absolute performance level

key_papers.title: In-season head-coach dismissals and the performance of professional football teams
key_papers.contribution: Most comprehensive study: 4 professional leagues, 2002-2015. Uses counterfactual reasoning to show dismissal effects are largely explained by regression to the mean.

key_papers.title: Performance Expectations of Professional Sport Teams and In-Season Head Coach Dismissals
key_papers.contribution: Introduces Monte Carlo simulation for computing pre-season performance expectations. Shows dismissal decisions are driven by deviation from expectations, not absolute results.

research_landscape.methodological_patterns: Dominated by pre-post comparison designs with limited causal identification strategies. Only Van Ours uses a quasi-experimental approach with control groups. No RCTs exist (infeasible for obvious reasons). Machine learning used for prediction of dismissals but not for causal effect estimation. Physical performance data emerging but limited to single-league studies.

gaps.title: No study uses modern causal inference methods (DiD, RDD) with post-2020 data
gaps.description: Most studies use simple pre-post comparisons or basic regression. Modern causal inference techniques — difference-in-differences with staggered treatment, regression discontinuity designs (e.g., around relegation thresholds), or synthetic control methods — have not been applied to coach dismissal. Meanwhile, 5+ years of new data is available since Van Ours's 2015 cutoff.
gaps.suggested_approach: Staggered DiD analysis across 10+ European leagues (2015-2026) using FBref match data. Treatment: coaching change. Outcome: points per game, xG, xGA. Use Callaway-Sant'Anna estimator for heterogeneous treatment effects.

gaps.title: Physical and tactical performance changes after coaching changes are barely studied
gaps.description: Only one study examines GPS/physical data around coaching changes. No study combines tactical data (formation changes, pressing intensity, build-up play style) with results data. Modern tracking data makes this feasible but the analytics community has not connected coaching research with tactical analysis.
gaps.suggested_approach: Use StatsBomb or Opta event data to measure tactical style changes (pressing triggers, pass networks, formation shifts) in the 5 matches before vs. 5 after coaching change.

gaps.title: Coach dismissal effects in women's football completely unstudied
gaps.description: All existing studies focus exclusively on men's professional football. Women's football has different league structures, shorter coaching tenures on average, and different market pressures. Effects of coaching changes may differ substantially.
gaps.suggested_approach: Replicate Van Ours methodology for women's leagues (WSL, NWSL, Division 1 Féminine) using publicly available match data.

gaps.title: No integration of coaching analytics with coach dismissal research
gaps.description: The platform contains substantial research on tactical analysis, performance analysis, and coaching effectiveness. But coach dismissal studies treat 'coach' as a binary variable (dismissed/not), ignoring the analytical profile of the coach (data-driven vs. traditional, tactical flexibility, etc.). No study asks: 'Do analytically-minded coaches survive longer?'
gaps.suggested_approach: Construct a coaching analytics adoption index from press conferences and tactical data, correlate with tenure length and dismissal probability.

gaps.title: No study examines the financial cost-effectiveness of coaching changes
gaps.description: Clubs pay substantial compensation when dismissing coaches (contract buyouts). No study combines the performance effect estimate with the financial cost to assess whether coaching changes are economically rational decisions.
gaps.suggested_approach: Combine performance estimates from DiD with Transfermarkt coaching salary data to estimate cost per marginal point gained from coaching change.

research_agenda.title: Causal effects of coach dismissal across European football leagues using modern econometrics
research_agenda.research_question: What is the causal effect of mid-season coach dismissal on team performance, controlling for regression to the mean, using data from 2015-2026?
research_agenda.methodology: Staggered difference-in-differences (Callaway & Sant'Anna 2021) with control group of teams that underperformed similarly but did NOT dismiss their coach
research_agenda.data_requirements: FBref match results for 10+ European leagues (2015-2026). Coaching change dates from Transfermarkt. ~50,000+ matches, ~500+ coaching changes. All publicly available.

research_agenda.title: Tactical disruption or tactical reset? Measuring style changes after coaching transitions
research_agenda.research_question: Do coaching changes lead to measurable changes in playing style (pressing, possession, formation), and do style changes predict subsequent performance changes?
research_agenda.methodology: Event data analysis + difference-in-differences on tactical metrics
research_agenda.data_requirements: StatsBomb open data or FBref advanced stats (xG, pressing stats, passing networks) for leagues with frequent coaching changes. ~200+ coaching changes with pre/post match data.

research_agenda.title: Coach dismissal and performance in women's professional football: a multi-league analysis
research_agenda.research_question: Do coach dismissal effects differ between men's and women's professional football?
research_agenda.methodology: Comparative pre-post analysis replicating Van Ours (2024) methodology for women's leagues
research_agenda.data_requirements: WSL, NWSL, and UWCL match results + coaching change dates. FBref has women's league data from 2018+.

strengths: Identifies specific methodological gaps (causal inference) that are actionable
Each research agenda item references concrete available datasets (FBref, Transfermarkt)
Honest about the limited number of directly matching papers in the platform database
Connects coach dismissal research to the platform's broader tactical analysis literature
limitations: Only 8 papers found in the platform database — this is a narrow evidence base
Agent cannot access full-text PDFs; analysis is based on titles, abstracts, and metadata only

The platform's classification taxonomy does not have a specific 'coaching_decisions' or 'managerial_economics' theme, so relevant papers may be classified under 'coaching' or 'performance_analysis' without clear identification
Non-English language papers may be underrepresented (relevant Dutch and German studies exist)
coverage_gaps: The platform appears to underrepresent the sports economics literature on coaching. Prominent researchers like Jan van Ours (Erasmus University), Bas ter Weel, Alex Bryson, and others have substantial bodies of work on coach dismissal that should be in the database. This suggests the platform's journal coverage may not fully capture sports economics journals.
Working papers on coaching effects from IZA (Institute of Labor Economics) and similar repositories may not be indexed
The Eredivisie (Dutch football) has been a popular empirical setting for coach dismissal research — papers specifically studying Dutch football may be missing
